problem.statement: Lack of accessible, real-time local air quality data in urban and semi-urban areas of Nigeria, hindering public health awareness and environmental policy decisions.
constraints: Low-cost implementation to ensure accessibility and affordability.
Reliable data collection and transmission in varying environmental conditions.
User-friendly data visualization for non-technical users.
Internet connectivity dependency for data transmission.
Scalability for wider deployment across multiple locations.

architecture.overview: The system utilizes an MQ-135 multi-gas sensor connected to an ESP8266 microcontroller. The ESP8266 reads analog sensor data, processes it, and transmits it via its integrated Wi-Fi module to Google Firebase Realtime Database. A custom web page, developed using Flask/Django, retrieves data from Firebase for real-time visualization and alerting.
block_diagram: ESP8266 MCU (Integrated Wi-Fi) -> Local Wi-Fi Network -> Internet
Google Firebase Realtime Database -> Custom Web Page (Flask/Django Backend)
Custom Web Page (HTML/CSS/JS Frontend) -> User Display

components.why_chosen: Detects a wide range of gases including NH3, NOx, alcohol, benzene, smoke, CO2, providing a general air quality indication at a very low cost.
pros: Good for general air quality monitoring
cons: Low selectivity (cannot distinguish specific gases precisely)
Output sensitive to humidity and temperature

components.why_chosen: Integrates Wi-Fi connectivity, sufficient processing power for sensor data, and is extremely cost-effective, making it ideal for budget-constrained IoT projects.
cons: Limited GPIO pins compared to ESP32
Lower processing power for complex tasks

components.why_chosen: Leverages the built-in Wi-Fi capabilities of ESP microcontrollers, providing a direct and cost-effective method for connecting to local Wi-Fi networks and the internet.
pros: No additional hardware cost (if using ESP)
Fast data transfer rates within range
cons: Limited range, susceptible to signal interference
Not suitable for remote areas without Wi-Fi access

components.why_chosen: Simplest and most common method for powering low-power electronics, suitable for fixed installations with access to grid power or for portable applications with power banks.
cons: Requires constant access to grid power or frequent power bank charging
Not suitable for long-term remote deployment

components.why_chosen: A highly scalable NoSQL cloud database that provides real-time data synchronization across clients, making it powerful for dynamic web and mobile applications with IoT data backends.
pros: Real-time data updates across all connected clients
cons: Requires more coding effort for integration
Can be overkill for simple logging tasks
Understanding data structure and security rules can be complex

components.why_chosen: Offers complete control over the user experience, design, and functionality, allowing for a tailored interface that can display data, trigger alerts, and potentially control devices.
pros: Can be hosted on inexpensive web servers
Enables advanced features beyond basic visualization
cons: Requires significant web development skills (frontend & backend)
More time-consuming to develop and maintain
Higher hosting costs for custom solutions

execution_steps: **Hardware Prototyping & Assembly:** Source MQ-135 sensor, ESP8266 NodeMCU, breadboard, wires, and a 5V power supply. Connect MQ-135 analog output to an ADC pin on ESP8266. Power the ESP8266 via USB.

**ESP8266 Firmware Development:** Set up Arduino IDE/PlatformIO for ESP8266. Develop firmware to initialize Wi-Fi, connect to local network. Implement code to read analog data from MQ-135. Convert raw ADC values to an approximate air quality index. Implement Firebase SDK for ESP8266 to push sensor data to Firebase Realtime Database/Firestore.

**Cloud Platform Setup (Firebase):** Create a new Firebase project. Set up Realtime Database/Firestore instance. Define data structure for storing sensor readings. Configure security rules for read/write access from the ESP8266.

**Custom Web Page Development:** Develop a backend (e.g., Flask/Django) to serve the web page and interact with Firebase. Create a frontend (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) to display real-time air quality data. Implement charting libraries to visualize historical data. Add functionality for displaying current status and potential alert indicators.

**System Integration & Testing:** Deploy ESP8266 firmware and verify data appears in Firebase. Host the custom web page and verify it fetches and displays real-time data correctly. Conduct end-to-end testing of data flow from sensor to UI. Test system stability and Wi-Fi connectivity robustness.

**Enclosure Design & Fabrication:** Design a protective enclosure (e.g., 3D printed or off-the-shelf IP-rated box) for the sensor and MCU, ensuring proper ventilation for the sensor and environmental protection.

**Deployment (Pilot Phase):** Deploy a few units in selected locations within Nigeria (e.g., a home, office, or public space). Monitor performance, data accuracy, and system reliability in real-world conditions.

methods: Unit testing of individual components (sensor readings, Wi-Fi connectivity, Firebase write operations).
Integration testing: End-to-end data flow verification from sensor to cloud to UI.
Environmental testing: Operate system in varying temperatures and humidity (within sensor limits) to observe data consistency.
Long-term reliability testing: Continuous operation for several days/weeks to identify data dropouts or system failures.
Functional testing: Verify the web interface accurately displays real-time and historical data, and alerts function as designed.
testing.success_criteria: Sensor data is transmitted to Firebase with less than 5% packet loss over 24 hours. Web interface displays real-time air quality readings updated every minute. System operates continuously for a minimum of 7 days without manual intervention or data loss. MQ-135 sensor readings correlate reasonably with known environmental conditions. The system can be set up and configured by a technician in less than 30 minutes.

extensions: Integration of additional sensors (e.g., PM2.5, BME280 for temp/humidity/pressure) for more comprehensive data.
Development of a mobile application for data visualization and alerts.
Implementation of machine learning models for anomaly detection or predictive air quality forecasting.
Solar panel integration for truly off-grid long-term deployment.
Local data storage (e.g., SD card) as a fallback in case of internet outage.
Geographic mapping of sensor locations and data points.
cost: Estimated hardware cost: $10 - $30 per unit. Estimated software development and initial basic web hosting cost: $100 - $300 (excluding professional developer fees for custom web page, which can be higher). Firebase free tier (Spark Plan) covers initial data storage needs.
skills: Embedded C/C++ programming (Arduino/ESP-IDF). IoT protocols (MQTT/HTTP for Firebase interaction). Wi-Fi networking fundamentals. Basic electronics and soldering. Web development (Python/Flask/Django, HTML, CSS, JavaScript, database integration). Cloud platform management (Firebase configuration, security rules). Data visualization techniques.
